case_name: Commissioner of Income-Tax, Central, Calcutta v. Gold Mohore Investment Co. Ltd.

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 1236 and 1237 of 1967 filed by Commissioner of Income-Tax, Central, Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 1236 and 1237 of 1967. Appeal from the judgment and order dated April 27, 1963 of the Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 65 of 1954.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated April 27, 1963 of Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 65 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated April 27, 1963 of the Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 65 of 1954. Sen, T. A. Ramachandran and R. N. Sachthey, for the appellant  in both the appeals .

facts.text: Appeals arise out of Income-tax Reference 65/54 decided by Calcutta High Court on August 27, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: These are two appeals by the Commis- sioner of Income-Tax, Central, Calcutta against Messrs. Gold Mohore Investment Co. Ltd. and arise out of Income-tax Reference 65/54 decided by the Calcutta High Court on August 27, 1963.

facts.text: Point involved is valuation of bonus shares in assessment years ending March 31, 1950 and 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The point involved in the appeals is the valuation of bonus shares in the assessment years ending March 31, 1950 and 1951. respectively. The previous years companyresponding to the assessment years were the financial years ending 31st March, 1949 and 1950,

facts.text: Assessee Company is a dealer in shares and values stocks at cost at opening and closing.

anchor.surface_text: The Assessee Company is a dealer in shares. Its method of valuation at the opening and closing of the stocks is to value shares at companyt.

facts.text: In Assessment Year 1949-50, Company held 2,500 shares of face value Rs. 10 each in Howrah Mills Co. Ltd. purchased at Rs. 85 per share, total cost Rs. 2,12,500.

anchor.surface_text: In the Assessment Year 1949-50 the Company held 2,500 shares of the face value of Rs. 10 each in the Howrah Mills Co. Ltd. They had been purchased at Rs. 85 per share and the total companyt to the Assessee Company was Rs. 2,12,500.

facts.text: In June 1948, Howrah Mills issued bonus shares in proportion of three shares for every two original shares, ranking pari passu.

anchor.surface_text: In June, 1948 bonus shares were issued by the Howrah Mills Co. Ltd. in proportion of three shares for every two original shares. The bonus shares were to rank pari passu with the old shares.

facts.text: Assessee obtained 3750 bonus shares of face value Rs. 10 each.

anchor.surface_text: As a result, the Ass-essee Company obtained 3750 shares of the face value of Rs. 10 each.

facts.text: On August 2, 1948, Assessee sold original 2500 shares for Rs. 72,087/8 (about Rs. 29 per share).

anchor.surface_text: On August 2, 1948, the Assessee Company sold the original shares for Rs. 72,087/8, i.e. at about Rs. 29 per share.

facts.text: On March 18, 1949, Assessee sold 3,750 shares for Rs. 95,250 (Rs. 25 per share).

anchor.surface_text: On March 18, 1949 the Assessee Company sold 3,750 shares for Rs. 95,250, that is to say, at Rs. 25 per share.

facts.text: Assessee computed loss of Rs. 84,041/12 on Howrah Mills shares.

anchor.surface_text: The Assessee Company companyputed a loss of Rs. 84,041/12. It calculated the loss in the following manner Dr.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer computed loss as Rs. 46,541/12 on Howrah Mills shares.

anchor.surface_text: According to him the loss was Rs. 46,541-12-0 as follows Dr. Sold Cr. Rs. a.P. Rs. a.p.

facts.text: Tribunal accepted Income-tax Officer's method for 1949-50.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal to the Tribunal as to which method was companyrect, the Tribunal accepted the method of valuation of the Income- tax Officer.

facts.text: In Assessment Year 1950-51, Assessee held 122 first preference shares of Fort Gloster Jute Company Ltd. costing Rs. 22,883/12.

anchor.surface_text: In the Assessment year 1950-51, the account year being 1949- 50, the Assessee Company held 122 first preference shares of Fort Gloster Jute Company Ltd. which had companyt to the assessee companypany Rs. 22,883/12/-

facts.text: Fort Gloster issued bonus shares second preference, Assessee received 137 shares face value Rs. 100 each.

anchor.surface_text: In the year of account there was an issue of bonus shares  second preference  and the Assessee Company received 137 shares of the face value of Rs. 100 each.

facts.text: Assessee sold 125 second preference shares for Rs. 14,500.

anchor.surface_text: The Assessee Company sold 125 shares  second preference  for Rs. 14,500.

facts.text: Assessee returned profit of Rs. 1,997 on Fort Gloster shares.

anchor.surface_text: The AssesseeCompany returned a profit of Rs. 1,997 as follows Dr. Rs. a.p. Cr. Rs. a.p.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer computed profit Rs. 2,973 by spreading cost over old and new shares.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer spread out the companyt of 122 1st preference shares  Rs. 23,883/12  over the 122 shares  first preference  and 137 shares  second preference .

facts.text: Tribunal confirmed Income-tax Officer's assessment for 1950-51.

anchor.surface_text: The Tiibunal companyfirmed the assessment as made by the Income- tax Officer.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner confirmed Income-tax Officer's order in each case.

anchor.surface_text: It may be pointed out that the Appellate Assistant Commissioner had in each case companyfirmed the order of the Income Officer.

facts.text: Tribunal referred questions to High Court on valuation of bonus shares for both years.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Appellate Tribunal then made a reference to the High Court and referred the following questions for the determination of the High Court 1949-50. Whether in the facts and circumstances herein stated the assessee...

facts.text: High Court held in favour of Assessee by judgment dated August 27, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, by its judgment dated August 27, 1963, following its decision in Income-tax reference No. 54/1960  from which Civil Appeal 1239 of 1967 is also being decided today  held in favour of the Assessee Company.

facts.text: Supreme Court reversed Patna High Court decision in Dalmia Investment Company Ltd. v. CIT reported in 41 ITR 705.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sen, in dealing with these appeals, points out that the decision of the Patna High Court in 41 I.T.R. 705 was reversed by this Court in Commissioner of Income-tax, Bihar Dalmia Investment Co. Ltd. 2

facts.text: Supreme Court approves method of spreading cost of original shares over old and bonus shares where pari passu.

anchor.surface_text: He companytends that the method adopted by the Income- tax Officer in relation to the Fort Gloster Jute shares is the method approved of by this Court, namely, that where the shares are pari passu and the valuation is to be made at companyt, the price of the original shares must be spread over the old and the new shares
The Assessee Company is a dealer in shares. Its method of valuation at the opening and closing of the stocks is to value shares at cost.

concepts.unlisted_description: Method of valuing shares stock at cost for dealers in shares at opening and closing of accounting period for income tax purposes.

anchor.surface_text: The bonus shares were to rank pari passu with the old shares.

concepts.interpretation: Bonus shares ranking equally with original shares, treated collectively for cost allocation.
concepts.unlisted_description: Bonus shares that rank equally (pari passu) with original shares.

anchor.surface_text: where the shares are pari passu and the valuation is to be made at cost, the price of the original shares must be spread over the old and the new shares

concepts.unlisted_description: Bonus shares that rank equally (pari passu) with original shares.

concepts.interpretation: Condition precedent for applying the average cost spreading method.
concepts.unlisted_description: Bonus shares that rank equally (pari passu) with original shares.

anchor.surface_text: He contends that the method adopted by the Income- tax Officer in relation to the Fort Gloster Jute shares is the method approved of by this Court, namely, that where the shares are pari passu and the valuation is to be made at cost, the price of the original shares must be spread over the old and the new shares

concepts.interpretation: Spread the cost of original shares over original and bonus shares to arrive at average cost per share for profit/loss computation.
concepts.unlisted_label: Average Cost Method for Bonus Shares
concepts.unlisted_description: Rule for apportioning cost of original shares to bonus shares ranking pari passu by averaging for income tax assessment in share trading.

concepts.interpretation: Court reaffirms this as correct method after reconsidering Emerald case distinction.
concepts.unlisted_label: Average Cost Method for Bonus Shares
concepts.unlisted_description: Rule for apportioning cost of original shares to bonus shares ranking pari passu by averaging for income tax assessment in share trading.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Appellate Tribunal then made a reference to the High Court and referred the following questions for the determination of the High Court 1949-50. Whether in the facts and circumstances herein stated the assessee...

concepts.unlisted_label: Income Tax Reference to High Court
concepts.unlisted_description: Tribunal's reference of questions of law to High Court in income tax appeals.

concepts.interpretation: Court follows its prior ruling in Dalmia unless clear error, distinguishes Emerald as not deciding the issue fully.
concepts.unlisted_description: Binding nature of Supreme Court precedents on lower courts and itself unless per incuriam or error.

anchor.surface_text: The first method is to take the cost as equivalent to the face value of the bonus shares. This method was followed by the Assessee Company.

concepts.unlisted_label: Face Value as Cost of Bonus Shares
concepts.unlisted_description: Incorrect method of valuing bonus shares at their face value for cost computation.

concepts.interpretation: Rejected in favour of average cost method.
concepts.unlisted_description: Method valuing bonus shares at zero cost, partially used by ITO but not fully approved.

issues.text: Whether in the facts and circumstances herein stated the assessee carrying on share dealing business, can add Rs. 37,500 being the face value of bonus shares issued to it free of companyt on the basis of its old share-holding, as companyt of its share holding for the purpose of determining loss in dealing in Howrah Mills Co. Ltd. shares?

Ltd. shares?

holdings.text: the correct method to apply in cases where bonus shares rank pari passu is to follow the third method, namely, to take the cost of the original shares and to spread it over all the original as well as the bonus shares and to find out the average price of all the shares
holdings.reasoning_summary: Reaffirmed the holding from Dalmia Investment Co. Ltd. case after considering four possible methods of valuation

holdings.text: We have considered the matter once-again and are of opinion that the method followed in the Dalmias case is the correct method
holdings.reasoning_summary: Reconsidered in light of invitation to depart based on Emerald but confirmed Dalmia method as correct

holdings.text: In any case that case [Emerald] did not decide the matter fully because as the Court itself observed the difference in the two methods only resulted in Rs. 18 being either added to or deducted from the ultimate result
holdings.reasoning_summary: Emerald involved unsold bonus shares with negligible difference in methods, no final view expressed on bonus valuation
